newsitem.title: USA: China cotton imports seen halved 96/97.
newsitem.headline: China cotton imports seen halved 96/97.

text.p: Chinese cotton imports in 1996/97 will be half of last year's levels, said the International Cotton Advisory Committee, resulting in more supplies for the rest of the world and a decline in average market prices this season.

The advisory committee, an association of 40 governments of cotton producing and consuming countries, said imports by China are estimated at 300,000 tons in 1996/97, less than half of last season's Chinese imports of 663,000 tons.
The average market price for cotton this season is expected to be around 78 cents per pound, down from the 1995/96 level of 85.61 cents per pound.

Wrold cotton production is estimated at 18.7 million tons in 1996/97, and 19.6 million tons next season. Consumption is estimated at levels similar to production, 18.9 million tons this season and 19.5 million next season.
With production and consumption at an approximate balance, changes in stocks are likely to be small and movements in prices are likely to be modest.

World cotton consumption is forecast to rise to more than 20 million tons over the next five seasons, resulting in upward pressure on prices. Average cotton prices are expected to rise to between 80 and 90 cents per pound by 2000/01.
